a couple of question.

1. for the fuel pod retrieval challenge, the abort to orbit, after i shut down the main engines do i need to get to orbit or head back immediately for KSC? 

2. for the STS ComSat Deployment & Servicing can i use a stock part solution to retrieve the defunct satellite for the commander badge?

> 
> a couple of question.
> 1. for the fuel pod retrieval challenge, the abort to orbit, after i shut down the main engines do i need to get to orbit or head back immediately for KSC? 
> 
> 2. for the STS ComSat Deployment & Servicing can i use a stock part solution to retrieve the defunct satellite for the commander badge?

1. For ATO, get to orbit, and then land at KSC (so you'll be going around Kerbin at least once). You are also welcome to leave it up there and go for a docking with any fuel pod in orbit to complete the other goals in the mission concurrently. But ATO means abort to orbit... so you have to at least make it to orbit as part of misssion. What you do after that is up to you, either continue the mission and then land on the africa land mass or ksc (if going for pilot or commander), or make preparations to land back at the africa land mass or KSC when you come around again.

2. if you can use a stock solution, go for it! No restrictions there. Be as creative as you wish. The sat does have to be in the bay and survive landing at KSC or KSC Island though if you're intending to capture it and return it for the Commander rating. Good luck! I look forward to what you can come up with!

Wow, I love this shuttle. And I love the idea of these Challenges. Thanks for putting all this work in inigma.

I started playing around with Intrepid over on the Reddit Challenge thread while trying to build my own (thanks so much for all your help over there, by the way inigma). I got so obsessed with playing around with this one, though, that I never even finished mine! (maybe that was your evil plan all along ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif) )

Below is an album from the maiden voyage of the **Space Shuttle Fortunate**.

I *believe* this qualifies me for Pilot I and the Hall of Fame, but I'm not great with instructions so I'll need a judge's ruling. Final fuel pod orbit 303,640/303,600.

A couple of notes on the mission:

(1) I'm thoroughly embarrassed to have brought home a whopping 499 units of monoprop. I was not sure how much I would need for the return burn, and my head was still in no-mods-Reddit-Challenge mode, so it didn't occur to me to check my dV with KER (*which was only a button-click away*!). Anybody know how much more altitude I would have gotten had I used that monoprop? Wait, maybe I don't want to know....

(2) I didn't encounter the random-wing-explosion bug that seems to be going around, but take a look at the shot towards the end as I taxi off the runway. Not sure what's going on there....

[EDIT - Add RTLS Abort]

Here's the almost-immediate, and slightly-less-successful, follow-up mission to the Fortunate, the **Space Shuttle Hubris.**

Hopefully it's not KSP blasphemy to create a story in which Jeb makes a piloting mistake. I didn't actually realize until I launched the Hubris that it hadn't been Jeb piloting the Fortunate. Good thing in the end...not sure anyone else could have brought this thing home in one piece.

Actually this shuttle is designed from various shuttles I studied by others, and represents, I believe, a convergence of optimal design. If anyone can design a more optimal space shuttle, let me know. I intended to create a good looking space shuttle for use on a private gaming multiplayer server with friends, and didn't expect it to fly so well. But in short, I figured out the design principles early and committed to them, and wow. Simple rule of shuttle design? Don't design it empty. Build it, test it, and balance it with a fully loaded cargo bay and whistles. Your maximum rating for launch, and maximum rating for landing. Since if you can make it fly heavy, then flying empty is already built in.
